What other dried fruits did you use in the earliest days? (apples, pears, apricots, peaches, loganberries, raisins, currents or others)? Mostly apples and peaches. We had the other in smaller quantities. It was several years later before we started carrying dried loganberries.

8. PRESERVING

In the early years did you preserve any foods by drying? Peas? Corn? Beans? Saskatoons? Other foods?

What year did you first preserve fruit by canning? 1913

What year did you first preserve vegetables by canning? 1913

What year did you first preserve meat by canning? 1913

Do you still preserve foods by canning or drying? Yes.

To what extent? 200 lbs.

Did you make your own vinegar?

We had 3 barrels of apples shipped here from the east (I was to pay a debt). The other two, we knew where to thank for them. This was in the winter of 1913-1914. When our shipping facilities were not complete. The apples were frozen solid. They looked worthless. We brought them inside a salted water bath. We filled all the vessels but 2 with water into a hot oven. We filled all the vessels with water. This was our first experience with deep freezing and we had no idea how well pleased with the result.

Mention any changes in the use of fuels which have taken place since you first started housekeeping, giving dates where possible.

We purchased an oil stove in 1925 for summer use. Most of our neighbors are now using oil for heating and propane gas for cooking. We still use a wood and coal stove for cooking. We got a wood lot from our wood lot at the present time. We have a pipeless furnace which was installed 1926.

20. Mention any outstanding differences in the preparation of meals in the earliest days as compared with today.

21. When did you begin to rely on purchased foods and prepared foods instead of homegrown and home prepared foods? (Give as many details and dates as possible).

22. Please add other details from your early experiences of buying groceries and securing foods in other ways during pioneer days in Western Canada. Include items not mentioned above, quality, methods of merchandising, prices, problems of storage, shortages and other details. [Use back of page if more space is needed].

Our fare hasn't changed a great deal since 1914. We use more fresh fruit now as much of the dried variety. In the early days we used sour docks and lamb quarters for greens (we still use them as they come earlier than the garden kind). Mushrooms were very plentiful, and for those who liked them made a welcome change of diet.

The homesteaders here made what they called homesteader's butter, bacon fat, and syrup beaten up together. 1/2 cup fat to 1/2 cups syrup.
21. Than did you begin to roll on prehistoric forts and prairie forts instead of horizons and prairie prairies (there are many prairies and prairies as prairies).

Our family started a new ideal in 1914. We were now going out into the early days. We had moved from the old house and started our own farm.

We used our own tools and land, growing our own crops.

The homesteaders were very friendly and for those who liked them.

It was a welcome change I did.

The homesteaders were made what they called homesteaders, little, brown pots.

And my cup tea time up together.
